pros: Working at WDW is an invaluable, formative experience I think everyone should have for at least a year or two. It teaches work ethic and customer service skills that you'll carry with you everywhere. There are also some terrific educational benefits due to the Disney Aspire program (and tuition reimbursement, available to some management positions).
cons:
This is a big company and their primary concern is (safety, but also) guest experience. Even the finest cast members can be treated as disposable considering what a big company it is and how coveted jobs here are. Everything changes quickly and constantly and you have to adjust.
Advice to Management
Coming from a veteran of three different departments, I can honestly say that the most fruitful locations for guest satisfaction are the ones where management makes a deliberate effort to build meaningful connections with their cast. If leaders focus on seeking out bad behavior, cast will quickly lose morale. The biggest management issue I've faced, and this is coming from someone who's obsessed with guest satisfaction, is a subliminal mentality that "the customer is always right," which ultimately tells cast members that they are disposable. I've talked with dozens of elder cast whose innocent love for the company was slowly spent by leaders who demonstrated that they don't truly care for their cast, or that their support ends where the guest experience begins. I don't think this is a majority by any means though. If the atmosphere feels as though each cast member is a professional, invaluable member of our team, we teem at the opportunity to "make magic".

pros: All Cast Members receive free park admission and discounts.
cons:
Disney pays below the industry standard. Opportunities for advancement/growth are limited and rely heavily on networking and/or personal connections. Advice to Management
During my time with the company, I held several managerial roles. The lower level management has their hands tied to be able to improve the working environment for their Cast Members. Senior level executives seemed more concerned with self preservation than about addressing concerns that really could make a difference. Feedback was discouraged and speaking up often meant being ostracized or reprimanded. Also, there needs to be a much greater focus on recognition. There is far too much emphasis placed on the discipline metrics and not enough focus on work/life balance, recognition and Cast development. Managers are expected to work 50+ hours/week and it is not uncommon due to the progressive scheduling practices to not have adequate time for recovery between shifts.

Good people who have worked at the company for 10, 20, 30+ years

cons:
Lots of reorganization in the company right now, bosses changing, groups changing, it seems never ending 
Each team is an island with little to no communication across to other teams, ideas are not shared and many tools are rebuilt over and over by different teams, very little company-wide collaboration
Huge company, can feel really lost at times
Pay is low in comparison to other big companies with tech positions 
There are a lot of contractors who are very awesome, very skilled - but this leads to a feeling like your team is not permanent and getting consistency in projects is very difficult

When your employees are going through years of reorgs, don’t take them for granted
Try to have more competitive salaries for tech employees 
Hire more full time employees so that teams can actually build rapport
Be more modern and allow employees to work remotely full time like they all want to

They've got several legal and technological departments, a moving set of standards that are essentially a la carte. Don't like a policy put out by infosec? That's fine! Just ignore it! Bring up an issue to have it addressed by leadership? Your immediate leaders will listen (which is good!) Once you're past director level they are so removed from everything that they don't care as long as they get them bonuses. People are/were on indefinite furloughs and teams are being ground to dust because executive leadership hasn't ever worked with a team that doe thing X so they don't know what to do with them and instead of learn they do the microsoft thing of Embrace, Extend, Extinguish. There aren't many opportunities that bubble up from within, at least not up north, down in california sure.
